#Text=Fort Ross
#Text=Fort Ross is a State Historical Park in the North Coast of California .
#Text=Although fairly remote , it is well worth a visit as you will become one of the few people who know about the Russia n contribution to the colonizing of California .
#Text=Understand
#Text=The fort is in a remote area with little food or services .
#Text=There is no cell phone service in this region .
#Text=History
#Text=Fort Ross was a Russian fur trade outpost in what is now Sonoma County , California .

#Text=It was established by the Russian-American Company in 1812 and sold to John Sutter in 1841 , owing to the depletion of the local population of fur-bearing marine mammals , and to the decreased strategic importance of a supply base for Russia 's Alaskan colonies following the Conventi on of February 28 , 1825 with the British .
#Text=It was the southernmost outpost of a Russian presence in the Pacific Northwest and Alaska .
#Text=The fort and the surrounding settlement was home to Russians , Aleut hunters in their employment , and native Kashia Pomo .
#Text=This unique site has been the subject of intensive archaeological investigation .
#Text=It is designated a National Historic Landmark .
#Text=Landscape
#Text=The fort is on a small peninsula that juts out into the pacific ocean .
#Text=The edge of the peninsula forms a large bluff ( 20 m ) that can make it somewhat difficult to gain access to the beaches .
#Text=Large coastal mountains covered in a thick forest tower over the park .
#Text=Flora and fauna
#Text=There is a wealth of wildlife activity in the region , particularly on the isolated beaches that run below the bluff .
#Text=Sea otters , sea lions and many impressive sea birds are abundant in the area .
#Text=Whales are also known to migrate along the coast .
#Text=Much of the beaches are covered in large piles of kelp ( seaweed ) with the occasional tide pool near by .
#Text=It makes for a great place to explore for wildlife but not great for beach swimming .
#Text=Climate
#Text=Warm in summer , rainy and foggy ( and occasionally sunny ) in winter .
#Text=Dress in layers , and if you are planning on swimming , expect the Pacific Ocean to be cold .
#Text=Get in
#Text=The most scenic way to get to Fort Ross from San Francisco is by driving up the Pacific Coast Highway ( Highway 1 ) .
#Text=Fees and permits
#Text=A day-use vehicle permit costs $ 8 .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Expect a bit of a walk .
#Text=From the visitor center and parking lot down to the fort proper it is a quarter mile walk .
#Text=To get down to the beaches expect about a 20- to 30-minute hike .
#Text=See
#Text=Old Russian Fort
#Text=Russian Burial Grounds
#Text=Russian Orthodox Church
#Text=Visitor Center ( nicely done )
#Text=Whales
#Text=Sea Otters
#Text=Sea Lions
#Text=Do
#Text=Hike along the beach
#Text=Cultural Heritage
#Text=Day - last Saturday in July every year , 10AM-5PM .
#Text=The fort comes alive with costumed reenactors , this is a fun way to see the fort as it was in its heyday .
#Text=Buy
#Text=There is a souvenir shop at the visitor center where you can get some great Russian memorabilia such as post cards with a historical California/Russia post card .
#Text=Eat
#Text=The fort does not offer much in the way of food so be sure and pack a lunch or expect to drive out of the park to a restaurant or local store to get some food .
#Text=Sleep
#Text=There are motels located about a half mile drive further up Highway 1 .
#Text=You can also just camp in your car , although it is not recommended that you do this in the Fort Ross parking lot .
#Text=Camping
#Text=Basic camping facilities are available to the south about a 2-min drive at The Reef Campground .
#Text=( Pit toilets , camp sites , dirt road , pay phone .
#Text=Cell phones do n't work here . )
#Text=Open most of the year .
#Text=Other camp grounds are to the north , 10-20 miles .
#Text=Back country
#Text=The coastal mountains that tower over the fort have some great hiking trails .
#Text=Just ask at the visitors center .
#Text=there are also hiking trails along the bluffs to the north and south of the fort .
